conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours (forbid notifications), while User Story B wants to receive all social invitations and calls freely without limits (start notifications). Both stories demand opposite actions on notifications at the same time, causing a direct conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.
resolutionDescription: Notifications are blocked for non-emergency only during work hours, allowing social invitations and calls outside work and emergency notifications anytime.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive social invitations and calls freely outside work hours and emergency calls anytime to stay connected.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to allow caregivers to control and possibly limit notifications to avoid overload, while User Story B wants the older person to receive all social invitations and calls freely without limits. These are opposite expectations on notification control for the same event.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can avoid overload and respect their wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: The caregiver's control over notifications is updated to include the older person's consent and preferences, while the older person's desire to receive social invitations freely is kept. This balances control and freedom using a context-aware policy.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manage notifications with the older person's consent, so I can avoid overload and respect their wishes.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to accept all notifications at night but select urgent ones, which means some notifications may be blocked or filtered. User Story B wants to receive all social invitations and calls freely without limits, which means no notifications should be blocked or filtered. These are opposite expectations on notification handling under the same condition (night or social calls), causing a start-forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to accept all notifications at night but choose which are urgent, so I can stay responsive without missing important alerts.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by refining User Story A to filter only non-urgent notifications at night while allowing urgent ones, and User Story B to emphasize receiving all social invitations and calls without filtering during the day or non-night times. This way, notification handling respects time context and urgency, balancing responsiveness and social connectivity.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to allow all urgent notifications at night while filtering non-urgent ones, so I can stay responsive without disturbance.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely during the day, so I can stay connected without limits.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to limit interaction times to avoid disturbing the older person, while User Story B wants to receive all social invitations and calls freely without limits. These two impose opposite instructions on notification control.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to follow clients' wishes for interaction times, so I do not disturb their daily routine.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.
resolutionDescription: Adjust both stories to balance interaction limits with social connection needs by allowing notifications during preferred times and limiting them outside those times.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to respect clients' preferred interaction times, so I avoid disturbing their daily routine.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive social invitations and calls during my preferred times, so I stay connected without being disturbed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and limit when social invitations are sent, forbidding some invitations to manage caregiver time. User Story B wants to receive all social invitations freely without limits. These are opposite expectations on handling social invitations.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when clients send social invitations, so I can manage my time and avoid feeling too busy.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive all social invitations and calls freely, so I can stay connected without limits.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by defining controlled social invitations with caregiver approval while allowing older adults to receive invitations freely within set limits, balancing caregiver time management and social connection.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control social invitations sent by clients, so I can manage my time and avoid overload.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to receive social invitations freely within caregiver-set limits, so I can stay connected safely.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to receive all notifications without limits, while User Story B wants alerts to be limited to avoid feeling too much. These two impose different frequencies of notifications that cannot be satisfied at the same time.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all notifications, including health updates and emotional prompts, so I can support my clients well.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who likes challenges, I want ALFRED to send alerts that keep me motivated without feeling too much.
resolutionDescription: Adjust both user stories to balance notification frequency by allowing caregivers to receive important alerts while older adults get motivational alerts that avoid overload.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive important health and emotional notifications, so I can support my clients effectively without too many alerts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person who likes challenges, I want ALFRED to send motivating alerts at a comfortable pace, so I stay engaged without feeling overwhelmed.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires the system to send all notifications including health updates. User Story B wants to block all app updates and installations, which may include notifications about these updates. This creates opposite instructions on sending notifications.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all notifications, including health updates and emotional prompts, so I can support my clients well.
userStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to block all app updates and installations, so that I avoid unwanted changes and keep full control.
resolutionDescription: Clarify that notifications about health updates are allowed while blocking app updates and installations, by distinguishing notification types and contexts.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all health and emotional notifications, so I can support my clients well.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want to block all app updates and installations except important health notifications, so I keep control and stay informed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants manual control to choose when to share data, which forbids automatic or full sharing at any time. User Story B wants to share all health data freely and in real time, which starts continuous sharing. These are opposite expectations about data sharing behavior.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually choose when to share each client's data to keep their privacy safe.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share all my health data freely and in real time with my caregiver, so she always knows my health status.
resolutionDescription: We apply a contextual policy layer that allows manual data sharing control by caregivers with user consent, while enabling older adults to set preferences for selective real-time data sharing. This balances privacy and timely health updates.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to share client data only with their consent to protect privacy and trust.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to share selected health data in real time with my caregiver to keep them informed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly and quickly for fast action, while User Story B wants alerts at a comfortable, motivating pace to avoid feeling overwhelmed. These specify different alert frequencies that cannot be fully satisfied together under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly so I can act fast without losing focus.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who likes challenges, I want ALFRED to send motivating alerts at a comfortable pace, so I stay engaged without feeling overwhelmed.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow configurable alert frequencies. The caregiver receives urgent alerts for fast action, while the older adult receives motivating alerts at a comfortable pace. The system adapts alert timing based on user preferences and context.
newUserStoryASummary: As a caregiver, I want ALFRED to show urgent alerts quickly so I can respond fast when needed.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older adult, I want ALFRED to send alerts at a comfortable pace so I stay motivated without stress.
